awd_titl_txt: Learning from Engineers to Develop a Model of Disciplinary Literacy in Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
Many students, especially those from underrepresented groups, opt out of engineering-related coursework because they do not believe that engineering is for them. Consequently, more effective K-16 instructional approaches are needed to help make engineering accessible and interesting to broader populations. This study draws from previous research in disciplinary literacy instruction, a promising teaching approach that has led to positive outcomes among underrepresented students in disciplines such as history and science. Under a model of disciplinary literacy instruction in engineering, students learn to read and write like an engineer through guided practice in evaluating and creating authentic texts in the service of engineering design activity. The purpose of this foundational research is to advance knowledge by developing a robust model of disciplinary literacy in engineering. To achieve this goal, the study will identify the common literacy practices used by engineers from four different sub-disciplines (aerospace/mechanical, biological, civil/environmental, and electrical/computer) who each work at different engineering companies. This study will describe the ways in which these engineers use shared frameworks to evaluate and create texts. This study will use these findings to develop a model of disciplinary literacy and curricular materials for use in K-16 classrooms. The exploration will establish the foundation for a trajectory of future research that will ultimately test the model of disciplinary literacy in engineering in diverse K-16 classrooms.

Although disciplinary literacy instruction has been shown to produce positive outcomes for underrepresented students in several academic disciplines, empirically-based models of disciplinary literacy instruction have not been developed and tested in the discipline of engineering. The purpose of this early stage design and development research is to advance knowledge by developing a robust model of disciplinary literacy in engineering that can be tested in diverse K-16 classrooms. A multiple, comparative case study will describe how eight engineers from varied companies and sub-disciplines (aerospace/mechanical, biological, civil/environmental, and electrical/computer) use literacy practices to solve problems through engineering. A constant comparative analysis of think-alouds, observations, and interviews with each engineer will result in the identification of common cognitive frameworks that engineers use while they interpret and generate core texts. These findings will be translated into a model of disciplinary literacy in engineering, with accompanying leveled classroom materials, designed to support K-16 students in thinking like an engineer as they read and write authentic genres in the service of engineering design activity. This instructional approach is expected to broaden participation by providing underrepresented students with literacy instruction designed to support their engagement with engineering. Future studies will test whether disciplinary literacy instruction leads to positive outcomes, such as an improved ability to engage in complex engineering design processes, among underrepresented K-16 students.

por.por_cntn:
Many studies have indicated that reading and writing instruction in science classes leads to a range of positive outcomes for diverse students. Despite this consistent finding, very little research has been conducted on the literacies of engineering, including what engineers read and write, and how they evaluate their own and others' writing. The purpose of this research, therefore, was to better understand engineers' literacy practices and to use this information to develop a robust model of literacy instruction in engineering, which could be applied across multiple sub-disciplines of engineering and which could inform literacy instruction at the middle and secondary school levels.

To achieve this purpose, we conducted ethnographies of eight engineers who held different roles in different organizations and who specialized in different sub-disciplines of engineering (aerospace, biological, chemical/industrial, civil, computer/software, electrical, environmental, and mechanical). We observed each engineer at the workplace twice per month for six months. During these observations, while being careful not to gather proprietary information, we recorded what they read and wrote, and how they talked about the texts that they read and wrote. We also interviewed the engineers each month, and we asked them to retrace their thought processes while reading or writing texts that were core to their work.

Analyses of these data sources indicated that engineers, including those who hold different roles at different firms, frequently used reading and writing to achieve a range of purposes. Across sites, on average, engineers engaged in distinct acts of reading or writing 59 times per every two hour period. Although all engineers frequently read or wrote texts that included written information, the genres of these texts (e.g., analysis results, schedules) varied based on each engineer's sub-discipline and based on their role within their respective company or organization.

Despite these differences, all engineers used common evaluative frameworks when reading and writing. Specifically, they asked the following questions relative to the content of a variety of texts: Is it accurate? Is it consistent? Does it meet standards? Is it up to date? Is it executable and reproducible? Is it concise and clear? In order to evaluate each text according to these questions, the engineers enacted common literacy practices, such as cross-checking (comparing information across multiple datasets); cross-correlating (comparing information across multiple representations); color signaling (using different colors to highlight information); performing hand calculations; using existing templates; comparing with standards; asking peers to review their work; and verifying with the physical world.

These findings can inform literacy instruction in engineering when teachers use them to identify authentic texts and when they support their students in evaluating these texts using similar frameworks to those of engineers. At the same time, literacy instruction can aim to be transformative rather than reproductive when students have opportunities to critique or expand common engineering genres and frameworks by drawing from their own cultural and linguistic practices and values.

Over half of high schools in the United States offer engineering as a stand-alone course, and a majority of states include engineering in their K-12 science or technology standards. This study has broad implications for teachers of engineering in these courses.
